column4: is there a Linux app that can scan files (that may be concatonated) and figure out what the file(s) may be?
you can run "file weirdofile" to find out what the weirdo file seems to be.. if that's what you mean
I don't think it will work when more than one are joined though.. I think it expects one filetype per file
it seems to have partially worked - it's picked up the first of the concatonated files
it appears to be a zip file, if I change the extension and open it only shows one file (I am expecting three)
is there any way I can find the size and "dd" the other files from the conglomerate?

yes.. I think it looks at the first bytes in the file.. but I'm not sure.. going a scan of several joined files will be trickier.. perhaps you'll have to write this tool yourself.. I can't really see how it's useful in day-to-day usage
I'm looking at reverse-engineering my router firmware (at least in part) as I suspect it has some GPL code in it
who is this evil person that has joined your precious, but still unknown files, that you need so badly? =)
I'm looking at reverse-engineering my router firmware (at least in part) as I suspect it has some GPL code in it
oh.. well.. you're trying to split the firmware binary into separate files? .. well.. that sounds like a manual job to me.. a boring job at that =)
maybe if I extract the known file from the file and create a zip from it, then compare this to the original and try again
although this depends on knowing the exact format of the zip
I wouldn't really know where to start.. sorry.. and it
and it's hard to come up with some hints when I have no idea what the file looks like or what it does
I've been hacking at it for a while and there doesn't appear to be a simple solution, maybe a project for another day
